Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Co-Optimization of Sensing, Communications and Navigation of a Robotic Network under Resource Constraints

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robotic networks can have a tremendous impact in many different areas such as disaster relief, emergency response, and national security. The recent disasters such as Hurricane Sandy of 2012 or Japan's earthquake of 2011 remind us of the crucial role that unmanned autonomous networks can play as part of our society. The goal of this project is to introduce a new multi-disciplinary design paradigm for the successful operation of mobile robotic networks through the co-optimization of sensing, communications and navigation. In the robotics/control community, most existing work does not deal with realistic communication issues (such as shadowing and multipath fading) and ideal links/disk models are assumed for predicting connectivity. On the other hand, the communication and networking communities are not typically concerned with path planning and navigation. In a robotic network, path planning not only affects sensing quality but also impacts connectivity maintenance. This multi-disciplinary nature makes designing robust decision-making strategies for a successful task accomplishment in robotic networks considerably challenging and an open problem. Furthermore, a separate optimization of the given sensing, communications and navigation resources may not suffice for a successful operation under resource constraints.

In this research effort, the focus is on the impact of limited energy (both motion and communications), time, and bandwidth resources and on laying the foundation of the corresponding optimum sensing, communication and navigation co-design policies, which includes trajectory, sensing, connectivity, motion speed/power, and communication transmission rate/power optimization. In this approach, realistic probabilistic connectivity metrics are properly co-optimized with sensing and navigation goals such that each robot chooses a trajectory that allows it to maximize its information gathering while maintaining the needed connectivity. This framework answers fundamental questions such as when to invest in motion and when to invest in communications. The project also addresses task feasibility and the fundamental limits of information generation, gathering and exchange, which can provide key insights for resource planning before deployment.

Overall, this new co-optimization foundation enables the successful operation of robotic networks under limited resources and can thus have a tremendous impact on our society. This project also has a significant educational impact on minority and under-represented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work is focused on realizing the vision of an autonomous robotic network successfully achieving a given task in a cooperative manner.  We have introduced a new multi-disciplinary design paradigm for the successful operation of such networks through the co-optimization of sensing, communications and navigation decisions, bridging the gap between the two areas of communications and robotics.  The methodology allows the robots to accomplish the given task in a cooperative manner, while maintaining the needed connectivity, and minimizing their total energy consumption. We next discuss specific outcomes of this work along both lines of intellectual merit and broader impacts.

Intellectual merit outcomes: For a robust cooperative task accomplishment, the team has to realize certain connectivity among themselves or to an outside node.  Along this line, we have mathematically characterized the statistical properties of the distance to connectivity, using tools from stochastic differential equations and stochastic dynamic programming literature.  Such characterizations are important for an energy-efficient methodical design of a team of unmanned vehicles. We have then shown how the network can realize certain connectivity, while minimizing its motion energy consumption.  More specifically, we have proposed a framework, based on potential games and log-linear learning, that allows a robot to find the optimum minimum-energy path to connectivity, with guarantees of performance. We have also fully characterized the computational complexity of the optimum solution.  To the best of our knowledge, this is the first result of its kind in terms of proven guarantees of performance.

To enable proper connectivity, we have further shown how the mobility can be utilized to enable new forms of connectivity. For instance, we have proposed novel ways for cooperative communication via distributed robotic beam forming and routing.  This allows a number of vehicles to minimally move and cooperatively enable communication in an otherwise harsh environment in terms of communication quality.  The underlying enabling idea is the utilization of robot motion to emulate a series of virtual antennas at the optimum positions for beam forming.   

Next consider robotic sensing, data collection, and data transfer. We have then proposed a new methodology for the co-optimization of sensing, communication and navigation objectives in a networked robotic operation, based on an optimal-control approach.  More specifically, we have shown how to co-optimally design the load distribution, paths, and transmission power/rate schedules of the robots in a way that minimizes the total energy required for both motion and communication. We have finally looked at the role of human collaboration in this context and how the unmanned vehicles can ensure proper collaboration with remote human operators.

Overall, this work has resulted in new tools for the energy-aware optimum operation of a team of unmanned vehicles, and can thus make a significant contribution in enhancing the state-of-the-art in robotic network design.

Broader Impact Outcomes: Robotic networks can have a tremendous impact in many different areas such as disaster relief, emergency response, environmental monitoring, surveillance, and security. On the educational side, the overall outreach goal of PI's proposal has been to expose minority students such as Native Americans, female and Hispanic students, to the basics of wireless systems and robotics, two areas with great potentials to inspire the young minds.  Towards this goal, the PI has organized an outreach event for the Native American high school students and teachers of the Gallup Central High School. More specifically, the PI arranged for 5 students and 2 teachers of the Gallup Central High School to fly to UCSB for a workshop for minority students. Gallup Central High School is a rural school at the border of New Mexico and Arizona, mainly consisting of Native American and Hispanic students from low-income families.  To enable this event, the PI worked with the SACNAS program (minority program) at UCSB to enable the attendance of the students and teachers. Although the logistics of enabling the travel from a remote town in a different state was very time-consuming, the event became an instant success.  5 students and 2 science teachers attended a 3 day workshop, got to interact with PI’s lab, toured the campus and got inspired by college life. 

In the course of this project, the PI has also hosted a minority community college summer intern student in her lab for 2 summers.  The PI has also taken part in the UCSB minority program (SACNAS) by giving lectures and robotic demos to the incoming students.  Finally, the PI has also taken part in a career event organized by UCSB women in software and hardware (WISH), to talk to female students about careers in engineering and science.
